assets.asset: Yan Lianke. A chinese writer author of internationally acclaimed novel. "Serve the people" as well as others have been banned in mainland China.
Tiger Temple, a famous blogger and activist.
Liu Wei, an orphan, eating a bowl of noodles at his grandma's who struggles to support him.
A young girl, whose father, a migrant worker lost his job to the recession. Her family can't make a living on farming only.

Lei Shui Xiang, headmaster of Guan Shan (Gansu) primary school, holding awards. Devoted to the children, covered with academic honors, his monthly income of RMB 150(US$20) hasn’t changed in 25 years, in spite of repeated request to have his status changed.
Lu Chuan, filmmaker and director of the box office hit "Nanjing, Nanjing" (aka "The city of life and death")
Wang Jindong had his identity files stolen and sold by corrupt officials. With no records of his education it is now near impossible for him to find a decent job.
Zhao Quancheng a young nationalist, passionate about military uniform a visit at Beijing Military Museum.
Fang Tong, teacher at a traditional confucean school.
Wang Ming & Fan Baoyin two lovers on a bench of Tian An Men square where they meet once a week.
A follower of an underground church.
General Zou, a surgeon specialized in back surgery and head of Military Hospital 306 in Beijing.

Yang Jisheng, journalist and writer, at the office of the history journal Yanhuang Chunqiu, of which he is deputy publisher. Yang is the author of two books both banned in mainland China. "Tombstone", published in 2008, is the first thoroughly documented account of the great leap forward.

The TV host Rui Chong Gang before the broadcast of his popular economy show on CCTV2. Rui Chong Gang became popular after advocating on his blog for the closure of a Starbucks coffee situated within the Forbidden City.

Sidney Rittenberg, one of the few westerners to be a member of the Chinese Communist Party. Mr Rittenberg became a friend of Chairman Mao during the fight against the K.M.T.. He spent 15 years in Chinese jails in the 50's and during the Cultural revolution but always kept supporting the Party and the revolution. He eventually became a consultant for U.S. firms such as Microsoft, who needed help to set foot in China.
